properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 11 at 5:18AM EST by NWS Marquette MI
properties.description:
An Arctic cold front will push across Upper Michigan Wednesday
afternoon and evening bringing a burst of moderate lake effect
snow and extensive blowing snow from strong northerly winds
gusting between 30 and 35 mph at times. North to northwest wind
lake effect snow will become lighter late Wednesday night into
Thursday night as much colder and drier air pushing in from north
of Lake Superior results in finer snowflakes. The finer
snowflakes, however, will be more effective at reducing visibility
in blowing snow late Wednesday night into Thursday.

Much colder air moving in behind the front will also cause
temperatures to quickly plummet from northwest to southeast across
Upper Michigan Wednesday afternoon into Wednesday evening.
Temperatures dropping into the single digits combined with the
gusty north winds will cause wind chill values to dip as low as
20 below zero late Wednesday night into Thursday morning. As winds
diminish and back more westerly late Thursday night, clearing
skies will allow actual temperatures to drop into the double
digits below zero over interior portions of west and central Upper
Michigan by early Friday morning, perhaps as low as 20 below zero
at a few locations.

Those planning travel or outside recreation over Upper Michigan
Wednesday into early Friday will need to plan accordingly for a
sharp change to hazardous winter weather conditions. Please stay
tuned to the National Weather Service for the latest updated
statements and forecasts on this developing winter weather event.

NWSheadline: Arctic cold front to impact Upper Michigan Wednesday into early Friday
